questions.text: Identify the marked blood vessel in this MR Angiogram.
questions.explanation:
Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA)

There are various types of MR angiograms based on different principles and can be classified into non-contrast and contrast enhanced methods.

Non-contrast MRA

Contrast enhanced (CE) MRA

Time-of-flight (TOF) imaging:

  • It is the most prevalent method for Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) in clinical practice.

Phase-contrast MRA:

  • It is more sensitive for identifying slow blood flow and useful for imaging cerebral veins (MR venography or MRV).
  • Effective for detecting dural venous sinus thrombosis and venous stenoses.
  • MRA combined with gadolinium-based contrast agents is called contrast-enhanced (CE) MRA.
     
  • Excellent for quickly visualizing the carotid and vertebral arteries where a large field of view (FOV) is necessary.
     
  • Reduces artifacts caused by turbulent or slow flow.
     
  • Useful for assessing arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), aneurysms, and intracranial stenosis.
  • Two types are:
    • Elliptical-centric
    • Multiphase techniques

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever, malaise, and productive cough. Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia

options.label: B
options.text: Interstitial infiltrates are seen in Mycoplasma pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates is seen in malignancy

options.label: D
options.text: Aspiration pneumonia is more common in the posterior segment of the upper lobes and superior segment of the lower lobes

questions.correct_answer: A. Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

Specific Imaging Features

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Most common cause of community-acquired lobar pneumonia in adults.

Staphylococcus aureus
  • Common in debilitated patients / superinfection in influenza / secondary to IV drug abuse.
  • Cavitation common in later radiographs.
  • Pneumatoceles (seen in children during recovery phase).

Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • Occurs in elderly and alcoholics, usually involves the right upper lobe (RUL).
  • Bulging of fissures due to increased involved lung volume.

Legionnaire’s disease (Legionella pneumophila)
  • Rapidly spreading pneumonia from contaminated water sources (ACs, coolers, showers).
  • Also presents with diarrhea, mental confusion (hyponatremia), and shock.

Actinomycosis
  • Can mimic bronchogenic carcinoma.
  • Soft tissue/bone involvement (periostitis) – key differentiating feature.
  • CT: Peripheral homogeneous consolidation with central low attenuation and pleural thickening (diagnostic feature).

Atypical pneumonia (Most common cause: Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Atypical organism (lacks cell walls, resistant to penicillins).
  • Fine reticular/nodular shadows in perihilar region early, which may progress to consolidation (rare lobar involvement).
  • WBC count usually normal.
  • Presents with non-productive cough, absent/minimal sputum.
  • Not aspiration-related.
  • Common in poorly maintained air-conditioned areas.
  • Other viral causes: Influenza A & B, RSV, Adenovirus, Chlamydia psittaci, Coxiella burnetii (Q fever).

Varicella pneumonia
  • Predominantly nodular opacities (5–10 mm).
  • If persistent, may calcify, leading to miliary shadows on CXR.

Concept

Description

Anatomical Dead Space

Conducting airways where no gas exchange occurs (e.g., trachea, bronchi).

Alveolar Dead Space

Alveoli that are ventilated but not perfused, contributing to wasted ventilation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness, and recurrent episodes of eye pain with redness. On examination, they are found to have anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)
 

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

 

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)
 

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

 

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint

 
  • Juxta-articular sclerosis
  • Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes
  • Squaring of vertebrae

 
  • Bamboo spine

 
  • Trolley track sign
  • Dagger sign

 
  • Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae)

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

 

Clinical Tests:

For Sacroiliitis:

  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test
 

For Lumbar Spine:

Schober/ Modified Schober test


 

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Differential Diagnosis
  • Mechanical low back pain
  • Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis)
  • Degenerative disc disease
  • Fibromyalgia

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance
 

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases)
  • IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)
 

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

Conditions mimicking Ankylosing Spondylitis with spinal fusion
  • Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH) (Forestier’s disease)
  • Ossification of Posterior Longitudinal Ligament (OPLL)
  • Spondylosis (Degenerative Disc Disease)
  • Psoriatic Arthritis
  • Enteropathic Arthritis (IBD-associated)
  • Reactive Arthritis
  • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA)

questions.text: A 45-year old female met with an accident and was brought to trauma centre and X-ray pelvis was performed and image is given below shows Intracapsular fracture NOF. What is the management in this case?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Neck of Femur Fracture

Intertrochanteric Fracture

Location

Intracapsular (within the joint capsule)

Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule)

Age Group

Typically after 50 years

Typically after 60 years

Sex

Female > Male

Male > Female

Common Patient Demographics

Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls)

Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients

Mechanism of Injury

Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic)

Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients

Stability

Less stable, especially if displaced

Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location

Ability to Walk

May be possible in impacted fractures

Walking is not possible due to the instability

External Rotation Deformity

Less than 45º

More than 45º

Shortening

Less than 1 inch

More than 1 inch

Blood Supply Involvement

High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption)

Lower risk of avascular necrosis

Blood Loss

Less blood loss due to intracapsular location

More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures

Pain, Severity, and Tenderness

Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle.

Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible.

Treatment Options
  • Non-displaced: Internal fixation (Option D) (e.g., cannulated screws)
  • Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty (Option B ruled out), total hip replacement)

Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails)

Complications

High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis

Malunion is more common than nonunion

questions.text: Which of the following must be avoided in post cardiac arrest resuscitation care?

options.label: C
options.text: Revascularisation procedure if patient develops ST elevation post resuscitation

options.label: D
options.text: Bring the body temperature down to below 32 degrees, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive

questions.correct_answer: D. Bring the body temperature down to below 32 degrees, therapeutic hypothermia if unresponsive
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Key Considerations

Hemodynamic Support

Maintain MAP ≥ 65 mmHg with fluids and vasopressors if needed to ensure adequate cerebral and organ perfusion.

Oxygenation & Ventilation

Target SpO₂ between 94–98% to prevent hypoxia and hyperoxia-related injury. Avoid excessive ventilation (PaCO₂ should be maintained at 35–45 mmHg).

Targeted Temperature Management (TTM)

Maintain temperature at 32–36°C for at least 24 hours in comatose patients to reduce neurological injury. Cooling below 32°C is not recommended due to increased risks of arrhythmias and coagulopathies.

Coronary Revascularization

Patients with ST elevation post-resuscitation should undergo urgent PCI to improve outcomes. Coronary angiography may also be considered in select non-ST elevation cases.

Neurological Monitoring

Continuous EEG and serial neurological assessments are crucial to detect seizures and assess prognosis.

Glucose Control

Maintain blood glucose between 140–180 mg/dL to prevent hyperglycemia-induced neuronal damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best study design as per hierarchy of evidence?
questions.explanation:
Level

Study Design

Strength of Evidence

1a

Meta-analysis of RCTs

Highest - Combines data from multiple studies for stronger conclusions.

1b

Large RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial)

Strong - Best for causality, but single studies may have limitations.

2a

Cohort Study

Moderate - Observational, used for prognosis and risk factor assessment.

2b

Case-Control Study

Weaker - Retrospective, useful for rare diseases.

3

Cross-sectional & Case Series

Weak - Descriptive, no causal inference.

4

Expert Opinion & Case Reports

Weakest - No statistical comparison, potential bias.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of experimental study - Blinding Randomization Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria Statistical analysis
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

1. Defining Inclusion & Exclusion Criteria

Determines which participants are eligible for the study, ensuring a uniform population.

2. Randomization

Randomly assigns participants into groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to eliminate selection bias.

3. Blinding

Conceals group allocation from participants, investigators, or both to reduce bias.

4. Intervention Implementation

The experimental treatment is administered while maintaining study protocols.

5. Data Collection

Outcome measures are recorded systematically for further analysis.

6. Statistical Analysis

Data is processed using statistical tests to evaluate the treatment effect.

7. Interpretation & Reporting

Findings are interpreted, conclusions are drawn, and results are published.

questions.text: Universal health coverage (UHC) means that all people and communities receive the quality health services they need, without financial hardship. Which of the following are the challenges to implementing UHC?

options.label: A
options.text: Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support and access to quality assured products only in low income setting

options.label: B
options.text: The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision and financial burden

options.label: C
options.text: To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income

options.label: D
options.text: UHC only deals with financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all

questions.correct_answer: C. To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income
questions.explanation:
Principle

Explanation

Equitable Access

Everyone should receive healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status.

Financial Protection

Out-of-pocket expenses should not cause financial hardship.

Quality Care

Services should be effective, safe, and patient-centered.

Sustainability

Health systems should be designed for long-term viability.

Challenge

Reason

Limited Financial Resources

Low-income countries struggle to fund universal healthcare.

Healthcare Workforce Shortage

Lack of trained professionals, especially in rural areas.

Infrastructure Gaps

Inadequate hospitals, equipment, and medical supply chains.

Political and Policy Barriers

Differences in government commitment to UHC implementation.

Strategy

Description

Innovative Financing

Public-private partnerships, health insurance schemes, and global funding.

Technology Integration

Telemedicine and digital health solutions to expand access.

International Support

WHO and global organizations aiding low-income countries.

questions.text: Which of the following is the 1st to be formed by the migration of the epiblast along the primitive streak?
questions.explanation:
Stage

Description

Primitive Streak Formation

Forms along the midline of the epiblast, marking the site of cell migration.

Endoderm Formation

The first wave of migrating epiblast cells replaces the hypoblast to form the definitive endoderm, which later gives rise to the gut and associated organs.

Mesoderm Formation

Subsequent migration of epiblast cells forms the mesoderm, which differentiates into structures like the cardiac mesoderm and notochord.

Ectoderm Formation

Epiblast cells that do not migrate remain as ectoderm, which later forms the epidermis and neural structures.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with occasional palpitations, high blood pressure, and headache. He is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma. What is the preferred initial investigation?
questions.explanation:
Pheochromocytoma

Definition
  • A catecholamine-secreting tumour that arises from the chromaffin cells of the abdominal sympathetic chain/ adrenal medulla
  • Co-exist with neurofibromatosis, VHL syndrome, MEN syndrome

Clinical features
  • Classical triad: Headache (most common), profuse sweating, palpitation and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent)
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia and Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor (due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction)
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight Loss

The rule of 10
  • 10% are bilateral
  • 10% are extra-adrenal
  • 10% are malignant
  • 25-33% are inherited
  • Symptomatic patients do not follow the Rule of 10’s

Diagnosis
  • Measurement of the plasma fractionated metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test; hence, the initial investigation is preferred.
  • Increase 24 hour urinary VMA(Vanillyl mandelic acid) and metanephrines (Option D)
  • MRI is the investigation of choice. (Option B ruled out)
  • Biopsy and CT contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid hypertensive crises

Treatment
  • Adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice
  • Size<5cm- Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha-blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with flank pain and dysuria. The pain was temporarily relieved by intravenous analgesics administered at a nearby primary healthcare center. She is diagnosed with ureteric colic secondary to ureteric calculi. What is the most appropriate diagnostic modality in this case?
questions.explanation:
Investigations for renal stones:

Urinalysis
  • This is often the initial investigation performed. It can reveal the presence of blood (hematuria), white blood cells (pyuria), and crystals in the urine, all suggestive of a possible stone.
  • The pH of the urine can also give clues about the type of stone.

Kidney, Ureter, and Bladder (KUB) X-ray

It can detect some types of stones, particularly calcium-containing stones, which appear opaque on X-rays.

Ultrasound

(Option C ruled out)

It's particularly useful for detecting hydronephrosis (swelling of the kidney due to urine blockage) caused by stones and can be helpful during pregnancy when minimising radiation exposure is important.

Intravenous urogram (IVU)
  • It involves injecting a contrast dye into a vein.
  • The dye travels through the bloodstream to the kidneys, where it is filtered and excreted in the urine.
  • X-rays are taken as the dye passes through the urinary tract, outlining the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • This test can reveal blockages in the urinary tract caused by stones.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with foul-smelling breath and dysphagia. A barium swallow X-ray is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis (Chronic bad breathing)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia
  • Rarely can a coma develop in long-standing cases of pharyngeal pouches.

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

 

 

 
  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: The partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

questions.text: An intern assists in laparoscopic surgery, and the resident explains the instruments and operating ports. The surgeon then asks, "What is the angle between the camera port and the working port called?"
questions.explanation:
Angles of laparoscopy

Azimuth angle

It is the angle between the camera port and the working port in laparoscopic surgery; the ideal azimuth angle is between 30 - 45° to avoid clashing of the instruments.

Manipulation angle

It is the angle between two working ports, and the ideal angle for this is 60°.

Elevation angle

This term is more related to the vertical positioning of instruments or the camera in relation to the surgical field, not the angle between ports; the ideal angle for this is also 60°.

questions.text: Match the following diseases with their respective gene mutation: A. Familial adenomatous polyposis i. SMAD4 B. Juvenile polyposis ii. STK11 C. Tuberous sclerosis iii. APC gene D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome iv. TSC1
questions.explanation:
A. Familial adenomatous polyposis

iii. APC gene

  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by APC gene mutations on chromosome 5.
  • It is characterised by numerous intestinal polyps, which, if left untreated, have a high risk of developing colorectal cancer

B. Juvenile polyposis

i. SMAD4

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder that commonly affects children under 5 years of age,
  • It is characterised by pedunculated polyps, usually less than 3 cm in diameter.
  • It is linked to mutations in the SMAD4 and BMPR1A genes, part of the TGF-β signalling pathway.

C. Tuberous sclerosis

iv. TSC1

  • It is a neurocutaneous disorder resulting from mutations in the TSC1 (hamartin) or TSC2 (tuberin) genes.
  • Patients exhibit neurological symptoms like seizures, along with skin abnormalities.
  • The syndrome also includes hamartomatous polyps in the intestine.

D. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

ii. STK11

  • It is also an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the STK11 gene.
  • It presents around 11 years of age and is characterised by
    • Gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps, especially in the small intestine
    • Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (macules on lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, and extremities).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male had surgery for an ileal perforation. Due to significant contamination, only the sheath was sutured, leaving the wound open. Daily wound irrigation was carried out, and the wound was closed on postoperative day 5. What type of wound-healing mechanism is occurring in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Wound healing

Healing by primary intention

(Option A ruled out)

It occurs when the edges of a clean wound are brought together and secured with sutures, staples, or adhesives. Minimal scarring occurs.

Healing by secondary intention

(Option B ruled out)

The wound is left open to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialisation. This is common in wounds with significant tissue loss or contamination.

Healing by tertiary intention (delayed primary closure)

(Option C)

The wound is initially left open and then closed surgically after several days when it's clean and granulating. This is used for contaminated wounds to prevent infection.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with leg pain after walking 100 meters. On examination, there is an absent pulse in the bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial arteries, but no gangrene is noted. Intermittent claudication is suspected. Which of the following statements about this condition is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward

options.label: C
options.text: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking

options.label: D
options.text: Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest
questions.explanation:
Boyd's classification of intermittent claudication:

Grade

Description

Grade 0: Asymptomatic

No symptoms of claudication, even with exercise

Grade I: Mild claudication

Able to walk more than 200 meters (about 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade II: Moderate claudication

Able to walk between 50 and 200 meters (about 160 to 650 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade III: Severe claudication

Able to walk less than 50 meters (about 160 feet) before onset of symptoms

Grade IV: Ischemic rest pain

Pain occurs at rest or with minimal exertion

questions.text: What is the T stage for this tumour in the oral cavity?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Oral Cavity Cancer (AJCC 8th Edition):

T (Primary Tumor):

Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed.

Tis

Carcinoma in situ.

T1

Tumor ≤2 cm, ≤5 mm depth of invasion (DOI).

T2

Tumor ≤2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, and ≤10 mm DOI. (Option C ruled out)

T3

Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm DOI. (Option A ruled out)

T4a

Moderately advanced local disease - Invades through cortical bone, deep/ extrinsic muscle of tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face.

T4b

Very advanced local disease - Invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base, or encases internal carotid artery. (Option D ruled out)

N (Regional Lymph Nodes):

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤3 cm in greatest dimension.

N2
  • N2a: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral node, >3 cm but ≤6 cm in greatest dimension.
  • N2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤6 cm).
  • N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, all ≤6 cm.

N3
  • N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm in greatest dimension, ENE(-).
  • N3b: Metastasis in any node(s) with clinically overt ENE(+).

M (Distant Metastasis):

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

Stage Grouping of oral cancer

Stage 0

Tis N0 M0

Stage I

T1 N0 M0

Stage II

T2 N0 M0

Stage III

T3 N0 M0 or T1-3 N1 M0

Stage IVA

T4a N0-1 M0 or T1-4a N2 M0

Stage IVB

Any T N3 M0 or T4b Any N M0

Stage IVC

Any T Any N M1

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression?
What is the appropriate treatment for a patient who frequently experiences a sense of contamination in his hands and compulsively washes them, leading to distress and impaired performance?
questions.explanation:
Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

Contamination / Cleansing
  • Most common presentation.
  • An obsession with contamination followed by washing and avoidance of the presumably contaminated object.

Pathological doubt /checking
  • Second most common presentation.
  • Obsession of doubt, usually followed by compulsion of checking.

Intrusive/forbidden thoughts
  • Third most common presentation.
  • Obsessed with intrusive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts without a compulsion.

Symmetry/ordering
  • Fourth most common presentation.
  • Patient needs symmetry/precision, which results in the compulsion of slowness.

Other symptoms
  • Religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the following PTA conducted on a patient?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Air Conduction (AC)

Bone Conduction (BC)

Frequency Range

125 - 8000 Hz

250 - 4000 Hz

Indicates

Overall hearing sensitivity

Cochlear function

Normal Ear
  • Both AC and BC thresholds are within the normal range (Within 20db in all frequencies)
  • No significant A-B gap

Conductive Hearing Loss
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated (poorer hearing) compared to normal.
  • BC Thresholds: Within normal limits.
  • A-B Gap (>20db): Significant

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL)
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated to the same degree as AC.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal or absent

Presbycusis


 
  • AC Thresholds: Elevated, particularly in high frequencies.
  • BC Thresholds: Elevated with greater loss in higher frequencies.
  • A-B Gap: Minimal
  • Downsloping

Meniere’s Disease
  • Upsloping
  • A-B Gap: Typically minimal

questions.text: Most common hearing test done in neonates for screening:
Marshall's triad (punctate lacerations, bruises, and abrasions) is seen in which type of blast injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary blast injury B) Secondary blast injury C) Tertiary blast injury D) Quaternary blast injury

questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism

Features

Primary Injury

(Option A ruled out)

It results from blast waves and is often internal with no external signs.
  • Ears: Tympanic membrane rupture or inner ear disruption.
  • Lungs: Alveolar-capillary membrane haemorrhage (blast lung), most common cause cause of death in survivors.
  • GIT: Injuries to gas-filled organs are more common in underwater blasts.

Secondary Injury

It is resulting from shrapnel, debris & flying objects (propelled by explosion).
  • Penetrating trauma.
  • The characteristic Marshall triad, which includes bruises, abrasions, and punctate lacerations, is evident.
  • Commonly cause severe thoracic injuries, including lacerations of the heart and great vessels.

Tertiary Injury

(Option C ruled out)

Victims are thrown against solid objects by blast winds.
  • Blunt/Penetrating trauma.
  • Includes bone fractures and coup-contrecoup injuries.

Quaternary Injury

(Option D ruled out)

Encompass all other injuries not classified above
  • Flash burns from extreme heat.
  • Crush injuries and falls due to explosions.
  • Respiratory injuries from toxic dust, gases, or radiation exposure.
  • Psychiatric issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), may affect individuals even if they are physically unharmed.

questions.text: The compound shown in the image can be used in the treatment of which of the following poisonings?

options.label: A
options.text: Aluminum Phosphide B) Mercury C) Phosphorus D) Arsenic

questions.explanation:
Poisoning Type

Antidote

Mechanism

Arsenic

BAL (Dimercaprol)

IM, chelates arsenic for excretion.

Succimer (DMSA)

Oral chelation.

DMPS

IV, transitioned to oral chelation.

Copper

Potassium Ferrocyanide

Forms insoluble copper complexes, reducing absorption.

Penicillamine

Chelates copper.

Cyanide

Sodium Nitrite

Forms methemoglobin to bind cyanide.

Sodium Thiosulfate

Converts cyanide to thiocyanate for renal excretion.

Hydroxocobalamin

Binds cyanide, forming cyanocobalamin.

Dicobalt Edetate, Methylene Blue

Alternative antidotes.

Ethylene Glycol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase to prevent toxic metabolites.

Iron

Desferrioxamine

Chelates iron for excretion.

Magnesium Hydroxide/Sodium Bicarbonate

 

Note: BAL should not be used in iron, cadmium, or selenium poisoning due to formation of toxic complexes.

Precipitate iron, reducing absorption.

Lead

Sodium/Magnesium Sulfate

Forms insoluble lead sulfate.

Calcium Chloride/Gluconate

Promotes bone deposition of lead.

CaNa2EDTA + BAL

Chelation therapy for lead elimination.

Mercury

Sodium Formaldehyde Sulfoxylate

Reduces toxic mercury ions.

BAL (Dimercaprol)

Traditional chelator; oral agents preferred.

Methanol

Ethanol/Fomepizole

Compete for alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing toxic metabolites.

Opium

Naloxone

Blocks opioid receptors, reversing opioid effects.

Organophosphate

Atropine

Blocks muscarinic receptors to manage cholinergic symptoms.

Pralidoxime (2-PAM)

Reactivates acetylcholinesterase.

Phenol

Magnesium Sulfate

Absorbs phenol in the stomach.

Phosphorus

Potassium Permanganate

Oxidizes phosphorus into harmless phosphates.

Strychnine

Barbiturates

Depress CNS, preventing seizures.

Thallium

Prussian Blue

Binds thallium in the intestine, preventing absorption.

questions.text: Which among the following is not seen in heat exhaustion?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of thermoregulatory mechanism B) Altered sensorium C) Orthostatic hypotension D) Core body temperature below 105 °F

questions.correct_answer: A. Loss of thermoregulatory mechanism B) Altered sensorium C) Orthostatic hypotension D) Core body temperature below 105 °F
questions.explanation:
Condition

Cause

Clinical Features

Postmortem Findings

Heat Exhaustion

Prolonged strenuous activity with inadequate water/salt intake in a hot environment.
  • Nausea, vomiting, malaise, myalgia
  • CNS symptoms:(Option B ruled out) dizziness, fatigue, impaired judgment, psychosis (severe water depletion)
  • Moist skin, increased pulse, rectal temperature > 37.8°C

Non-specific

Heat Cramps (Miner’s/Stoker’s/Fireman’s Cramps)

Fluid and electrolyte depletion (dilutional hyponatremia), following vigorous activity and profuse sweating.
  • Sudden severe muscle cramps (arms, legs, abdomen)
  • Tender, hard, lumpy muscles
  • Flushed face, dilated pupils, dizziness, vomiting
  • Moist, cool skin, body temperature normal/slightly elevated

Non-specific

Heat Stroke


 

Failure of thermoregulation in extreme heat exposure

(Option A)
  • Sudden collapse-loss of consciousness
  • Skin hot, initially wet, then dry
  • Hyperventilation- tachycardia
  • Core temp > 40.5°C
  • Pupils contracted
  • Convulsions
  • Unconsciousness
  • Cerebral dysfunction
  • High fever
  • Absence of sweating
  • Congested lungs, intrathoracic petechiae (children)
  • Subendocardial hemorrhages
  • Brain congestion, flattened convolutions, petechiae in the 3rd/4th ventricle walls

questions.text: A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit-lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Phacolytic glaucoma B) Malignant glaucoma C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis D) Phacomorphic glaucoma

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacolytic glaucoma B) Malignant glaucoma C) Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis D) Phacomorphic glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Option D)

Phacolytic Glaucoma (Option A)

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork. 

 

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage B) Retinal detachment C) Vitreous hemorrhage D) Branched retinal artery occlusion

questions.explanation:
Definition

Pathological/degenerative/progressive myopia is a rapidly progressive error that starts in childhood at 5-10 years of age and results in high myopia (>-6D) during early adult life.

Etiology
  • Rapid axial growth of the eyeball outside normal biological variations
  • Genetic factors (major role)
    • More common in women than men
    • Autosomal dominant pathological myopia
    • Heredity-
      • Familial, more common in women and in certain races
      • Autosomal Dominant - linked to genes 18p11.31 and 12q21-23
      • Sex-linked recessive - high myopia (>6D)
  • General growth process (minor role)
    • nutritional deficiency
    • endocrine disturbances

Symptoms
  • Defective vision with considerable failure in visual function
  • Muscae volitantes (floaters)
  • Difficulty in night vision in very high myopes with degenerative changes

Signs
  • Prominent eyeballs, often appear elongated
  • Exophthalmos, especially in unilateral cases
  • Cornea is large
  • The anterior chamber is deep
  • Pupils are slightly large and react sluggishly to light
  • Fundus examination reveals:
    • The optic disc appears large and pale
    • Characteristic myopic crescent
    • Tigroid fundus
    • Myopic crescent (temporal to disc margin)

Complications
  • Retinal detachment (Option B)
  • Complicated cataract
  • Choroidal hemorrhage and neovascularization
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Primary open-angle glaucoma (associated condition)
  • Degenerative changes in the retina and choroid:
    • Chorioretinal atrophy at the macula

 

  • Foster-Fuchs spots

 

  • Lattice degeneration

 

  • Total retinal atrophy
  • Posterior staphyloma

 

  • Degenerative changes in vitreous:
    • Liquefaction
    • Vitreous opacities
    • Posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: Identify the fracture in the given diagram:
questions.explanation:
Class I

(Chevallet Fracture)

Class II

(Jarjavay Fracture)

(Option B)

Class III

(Naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture)

Cause

Blows from below

Impacts directed from the front

High-velocity trauma

Fracture Line

Vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

Horizontal fracture starting just above the anterior nasal spine, running backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage and vomer.

Involves external buttresses of the nose and ethmoid labyrinth.

Pig-like appearance with foreshortened, saddled nose.

Clinical Relations:
  • Assess for nasal obstruction and deformity.
  • Significant deformity might only develop later, especially in children.
  • Check for deviation greater than half the width of the nose, which may indicate a septal fracture.
  • Requires reduction of both nasal and septal fractures.
  • Look for signs of more severe injuries, such as CSF leaks, multiple dural tears, and potential cerebral herniation.
  • Evaluate for orbital and skull base involvement.
 

 

Le Fort I

(Option C)

Le Fort II

Le Fort III

Also known as

Guerin’s fracture or Transverse fracture

Pyramidal fracture

Craniofacial disjunction

Fracture line

Runs above and parallel to the palate, crossing the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates.

Passes through the nasal root, lacrimal bone, orbital floor, upper maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates

 

Note: can cause infraorbital nerve injury.

Traverses the root of the nose, ethmoid-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral orbital wall, frontozygomatic and temporozygomatic sutures, and the upper pterygoid plates.

Characteristic feature

Hanging palate and hanging teeth

Hanging maxilla

Complete detachment of the facial bones from the cranial bones

CSF Rhinorrhea

Absent

May be present

High risk of CSF Rhinorrhea

Elevation of superior eyelid (Option D ruled out)
  • Elevation
  • Abduction
  • Extorsion

Oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III)

Type

Motor

Origin

Midbrain (Oculomotor sulcus on the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncle).

Course

 

Components

1. Oculomotor nucleus (somatic component):

General somatic efferent (GSE) fibres emerge from this site and supply -

  • Superior division:

  • Superior rectus
  • Inferior division:
  • Medial rectus
  • Inferior rectus
  • Inferior oblique
 

2.Edinger-Westphal nucleus (parasympathetic component) (Option C ruled out):

General visceral efferent (GVE) fibres arise from this site and supply:

  • Sphincter pupillae- causes pupil constriction
  • Ciliaris

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are correctly marked?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: A. 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE
questions.explanation:
Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

questions.text: What is the normal artery-to-vein ratio at the optic disc margin?
What is a common ocular finding in pterygium?
questions.explanation:
Pterygium/Surfer’s eye

Pseudopterygium
 

Definition

Pterygium is a triangular encroachment of vascularized granulation tissue covered by conjunctiva in the interpalpebral area.

 
  • Parts: Cap, head, neck, body
  • Degenerative process
  • Pterygium like lesion
  • Due to cicatrizing conjunctival inflammatory overgrowth
 

Aetiology

  • Common in dry, sunny climates with sandy soils
  • Ultraviolet light is a probable factor
  • Usually elderly persons
  • Seen at any age
  • Caused by
    • Trauma
    • Chronic conjunctivitis
    • Thermochemical burn




 

Pathology

 

Histology shows collagenous degenerative changes in the vascularized subepithelial stroma.

  
 

Pathogenesis

  • Degenerative subconjunctival proliferation
  • Granulation tissue proliferates as avascularized tissue encroaches on the cornea.
  • Destroys the superficial layers of the stroma and Bowman’s membrane
  


 

Symptoms

  • Frequently follows a pinguecula
  • Often bilateral
  • Usually on the nasal side
  • Impairment of vision due to:
    • Progression into the pupillary area of the cornea
    • Induced astigmatism by corneal flattening in the axis of pterygium
  • Progressive pterygium: thick and vascular
  • Regressive pterygium: thin, pale, and atrophic
  • Ceases to grow but never disappears
  • A probe can be passed under the lesion
  • Can present as inflammed pterygium

 
  • Non-progressive
  • Can be at any quadrant of the corneal limbus
  • Located away from the horizontal
  • Attached to the cornea due to scar tissue
  • Adhered to the adjacent lid
  • Always stationary

Signs

  • A probe cannot be passed under the lesion
  • Fusch’s spots/Islets of Vogt: small discrete whitish flecks made of pterygial epithelial cells seen in progressive pterygium and are also called the cap of the pterygium.
  • Stocker line: linear epithelial iron deposition, seen in regressive pterygium.

 
  • A probe can be passed under the neck.






 

Management

Best left alone

 

Medical treatment:

  • Tear substitutes for small regressive pterygium with dry eye
  • Topical steroids for associated inflammation
  • Protection from UV rays with sunglasses

Surgical excision for:

  • Progression of lesion towards the pupillary area causing excessive astigmatism and visual impairment
  • Restricted ocular movements
  • Disfiguring
  • Diplopia







 

Procedures
  • Bare sclera technique:
    • The pterygium is excised from the cornea and conjunctiva, leaving a bare sclera
    • Associated with a high recurrence rate
  • Autoconjunctival graft
    • A piece of limbal conjunctival tissue from the same or the other eye or
    • An amniotic membrane graft is used to cover the bare sclera
    • Sutured at the limbus to cover the defect
  • Surgical excision with lamellar keratectomy and lamellar keratoplasty for deeply infiltrating recurrent recalcitrant pterygia
  • Old methods (not used now):
    • McRaynold’s operation
    • Postoperative use of beta irradiations

Post-operative therapy and care
  • Prevent recurrence:
    • Mitomycin C 0.02% drops
    • Complications like scleral necrosis, cataracts, and iritis

questions.explanation:
Chemical Injuries
  • Eye injuries caused by chemicals range from mild irritation to vision loss.
  • Sources of Injury
    • Domestic: Ammonia, detergents, cosmetics
    • Agriculture: Fertilizers, insecticides
    • Laboratory: Acids, alkalis
    • Assaults & Warfare: Acid attacks, chemical weapons
    • Self-inflicted: Malingering or mental health conditions
  • Alkali vs. Acid Burns
    • Alkali: More severe, deeper penetration due to saponification, hygroscopic nature, and soluble compounds formation.
    • Acid: Less severe, protein coagulation forms a protective barrier.

Clinical Stages
  • Acute: Conjunctival swelling, corneal epithelial loss, iris inflammation, possible corneal sloughing and staphyloma.
  • Reparation: Epithelial regeneration, corneal vascularization, iris inflammation subsides.
  • Complications: Symblepharon, recurrent ulcers, cataracts, secondary glaucoma.

Emergency Management
  • Immediate irrigation: Use water or saline for at least 20-30 minutes or until the eye’s pH is restored. A minimum of 2 liters should be used. (Option B)
  • Mechanical removal: Gently remove any chemical particles with a cotton swab, particularly in lime burns.
  • Necrotic tissue removal: Carefully excise dead conjunctiva and corneal epithelium using a cotton swab.

Healing & Complication Prevention
  • Topical antibiotics: Use broad-spectrum antibiotics like moxifloxacin to prevent infection.
  • Topical steroids: Control inflammation and anterior uveitis. Use cautiously after two weeks to avoid hindering collagen production.
  • Cycloplegics: Alleviate pain and dilate the pupil with agents like atropine.
  • Ascorbic acid: Promote wound healing and collagen synthesis using topical and systemic Vitamin C.
  • Lubricants: Use preservative-free artificial tears to keep the eye moist and support healing.
  • Autologous serum: Use serum eye drops to provide essential growth factors for healing.
  • Sodium citrate: Stabilise neutrophils and reduce collagenase activity with topical sodium citrate.
  • Doxycycline: Inhibit collagenase activity with oral doxycycline.
  • Symblepharon Prevention:Use a glass shell or sweep a glass rod in the fornices (spaces between the eyelid and eyeball) twice daily to prevent adhesions.

Complication Management
  • Secondary glaucoma: Control intraocular pressure with beta-blockers like timolol or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide.
  • Limbal stem cell deficiency: Consider amniotic membrane or limbal stem cell transplantation.
  • Pseudopterygium: Surgically remove abnormal conjunctival growth and consider autografting or amniotic membrane transplantation.
  • Corneal opacity: Consider keratoplasty or keratoprosthesis for severe corneal damage.

Implications

Chemical injuries can cause permanent vision loss, physical disfigurement and psychological impact despite treatment.

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. Heavy infection causes rectal prolapse.
questions.explanation:
Life Cycle of Ascaris
  • Host: Humans only.
  • Infective Form: Embryonated eggs with L2 larvae.
  • Transmission: Ingestion of eggs from contaminated soil, food, or water. (Option C)

 

Life Cycle Phases

Migratory Phase
  • L2 larvae hatch, molt to L3, penetrate the intestine and travel to the lungs via the heart.
  • In the lungs, they molt to L4, migrate to the pharynx, and are swallowed back into the intestine.

Intestinal Phase
  • L4 larvae become adult worms in the small intestine.
  • Females lay fertilized eggs in feces; unfertilized eggs may also be laid.

Development in Soil
  • Fertilized eggs become infective embryonated (L2 larvae) in 2 weeks under suitable conditions.
  • Unfertilized eggs disintegrate and are non-infective.
  • Embryonated eggs can survive for up to 15 years due to a thick eggshell and ascaroside, a resistant lipoprotein.

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features
  • Caused by the host immune response, larval migration, adult worm obstruction, and nutritional deficiencies.
  • Incubation: 60–70 days.
 

Pulmonary Phase
  • Symptoms appear within two weeks post-ingestion: cough, chest discomfort, and fever.
  • Severe cases may lead to Loeffler’s syndrome, characterized by eosinophilic pneumonia and transient lung infiltrates.
 

Intestinal Phase
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but malnutrition and growth retardation can occur, particularly in children <5 years.
  • Complications include intestinal obstruction, perforation, intussusception, or volvulus in older children.

Extraintestinal Complications

Larger worms may obstruct the biliary tree, causing biliary colic or pancreatitis.

Allergic Reactions

Reactions such as fever, urticaria, angioedema, and conjunctivitis may arise due to toxins released by adult worms.

questions.text: Covid-19 can be prevented through all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Pathogenesis of COVID-19

Host Cell Entry
  • Binding: Spike glycoprotein (S) attaches to angiotensin-converting enzyme-2 (ACE-2) receptors on lung type II alveolar cells.
  • Cleavage: Host proteases (e.g., TMPRSS2) cleave the spike protein, facilitating viral entry via the endosomal pathway.

Initial Inflammatory Response
  • Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Infection of the pharyngeal epithelium initiates ILI.

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
  • Damage to Alveolar Cells: Impaired type II alveolar cells decrease pulmonary surfactant, causing alveolar collapse and fluid retention.
  • Cytokine Storm: Increased immune cytokine release leads to:
    • Tissue damage and necrosis.
    • Impaired gas exchange and hypoxia.
    • Endothelial damage and microvascular thrombosis.
    • Pulmonary oedema and ground-glass opacities on imaging.
    • Fibrosis and respiratory failure.

Multiorgan Failure
  • Elevated cytokines may harm other organs, resulting in sepsis, septic shock, and acute kidney/cardiac injury.

Risk Factors for Severe Disease
  • Demographics: Age > 60 years.
  • Comorbidities: Diabetes, hypertension, COPD, CKD and cancer.

Definitive Host

Infective Form

questions.text: A gardener with lymphogranulomatous lesions presented to the OPD, Identify the organism shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features

Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.

Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.

Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.

Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.

Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
 
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.
 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to grow Mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.explanation:
Investigations

Purpose

Advantages

Limitations

Sputum smear

  • Initial screening for pulmonary TB.
  • Samples are stained using the Ziehl-Neelsen method or Auramine-O stain to visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB) under a microscope.
  • Quick and inexpensive. Can provide results within a few hours.
  • Low sensitivity, especially in cases of extrapulmonary TB or in patients with HIV.
  • Cannot differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis and non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM).

Culture Methods
  • Confirm the diagnosis of TB and assess drug susceptibility.
  • Solid Media: Sputum is inoculated onto solid culture media like Löwenstein-Jensen or Middlebrook agar.
  • Liquid Media: Automated systems like BACTEC or MGIT are used to detect growth faster.
  • The gold standard for TB diagnosis.
  • Allows for drug susceptibility testing.
  • Time-consuming; results can take weeks.
  • Requires specialized laboratory facilities.

Xpert MTB/RIF
  • Detects Mycobacterium tuberculosis and rifampicin resistance.
  • Method:
  • A cartridge-based system that performs nucleic acid amplification (NAAT).
  • Sputum or other specimens are processed directly in the cartridge.
  • Rapid results (within 2 hours).
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
  • Simultaneously detects rifampicin resistance.
  • More expensive than smear microscopy.
  • Does not provide full drug susceptibility testing.

LAMP (Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification)
  • Detects DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Method:
  • Amplifies DNA at a constant temperature without the need for thermal cycling.
  • Sputum or other specimens are used.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 hours).
  • High specificity and sensitivity.
  • Can be performed at the point of care.
  • Used for patients with HIV with CD4+ counts of less than 100 cells/μL irrespective of signs and symptoms of TB.
  • Less widely available than PCR-based tests.
  • Cannot detect drug resistance directly.

TrueNat
  • Point-of-care test for TB detection.
  • Method:
  • Uses a micro-PCR technology to amplify DNA.
  • Results are available within 60 minutes.
  • Portable and easy to use in peripheral health facilities.
  • Provides results quickly, facilitating immediate treatment decisions.
  

Line Probe Assay (LPA)
  • Detects TB and drug resistance (rifampicin and isoniazid).
  • Method:
    • Sputum samples are processed, and DNA is extracted.
    • Amplified DNA is hybridized to specific probes on a membrane strip.
  • Rapid results (within 1-2 days).
  • Can detect multiple mutations associated with drug resistance.
  • Requires a laboratory setup and trained personnel.
  • Not suitable for all strains of TB.

RFLP
  • IS6110 restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis is widely used for molecular epidemiological studies of tuberculosis.
  • Restriction enzymes Nru I, EcoN I, Pst I, and Pvu II were used to analyze IS6110 fingerprints in Mycobacterium tuberculosis strains H37Rv (virulent) and H37Ra (avirulent).

questions.text: All of the following are cold sterilization methods except?
DOC for fasciola hepatica?
TRUE about cryptococcus
questions.explanation:
Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis .

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
  • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
  • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

 

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

questions.text: Field test for malaria?
questions.explanation:
LAB DIAGNOSIS OF MALARIA

Microscopy (Gold standard)
  • Thick smear - for rapid detection of malarial parasite
    • Quantification is done under an oil immersion lens
      • + - 1 to 10 parasites per 100-thick film field
      • ++ - 11 to 100 parasites per 100 thick film field
      • +++ - 10 to 10 per thick film field
      • ++++ - more than 10 per thick film field
    • At least 200 oil immersion fields should be examined before a film is declared negative.
    • It can be used for the detection of malarial parasites as low as 20 parasites / μL
 
  • Thin smear - for determination of plasmodium species

 
  • Stains used - Romanowsky stain (Leishman, Giemsa or JSB stain)

Quantitative buffy coat test
  • RBCs with parasites are less dense; thus, concentrate just below the buffy coat of WBC on top of the RBC column
  • Acridine orange is used to induce fluorescence on the parasite, giving a fluorescent greenish-yellow appearance on a red background
  • Microscopic examination of a smear made using the buffy coat is done.

Kawamoto fluorescence microscopy

  • Fluorescent dye like acridine orange or benzothiocarboxy purine is used to stain the parasite inside the RBC
  • Parasite DNA is stained fluorescent green, and cytosol RNA is stained red
  • The slide is examined under the fluorescent microscope
  • Used for mass screening in field laboratory

Rapid antigen detection test

  • Immunochromatography is done using monoclonal antibody directed against the parasite antigen

Parasite F test

  • Monoclonal antibody is used to detect histidine-rich protein 2 (HRP-2), which is produced by asexual stages of plasmodium falciparum
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Can detect low parasitemia (40 parasite / μL of blood)
    • Can detect only the asexual stage of plasmodium falciparum

Dual antigen test
  • Detects Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) and Plasmodium falciparum histidine-rich protein (PfHRP-2)
  • pLDH is produced by trophozoites and gametocytes of all plasmodium spp.
  • PfHRP-2 is produced only by the asexual stage of Plasmodium falciparum.

Molecular method

  • PCR: Used for species determination and detection of drug resistance.
  • DNA probe: Highly sensitive and can detect less than 10 parasites / μL of blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with celiac disease?
questions.correct_answer: D. HLA DQ6 and HLA DQ11
questions.explanation:
Type

Definition

0

Normal duodenal biopsy

I

Normal mucosal architecture with increased intraepithelial lymphocytes

II

Hyperplastic crypts, but near normal Villi

IIIa

Hyperplastic crypts with partial villous atrophy

IIIb

Hyperplastic crypts with subtotal villous atrophy

IIIc

Hyperplastic crypts with total villous atrophy

Feature

Coeliac Sprue

Whipple's Disease

Tropical Sprue

Description
  • Autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten.
  • Systemic infectious disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei.
  • Malabsorption disorder seen in tropical regions.
  • Cause often unknown, possibly infectious.

Etiology
  • Genetic predisposition (HLA-DQ2/DQ8).
  • Environmental trigger: gluten (present in wheat, barley, rye) ingestion and an immune response to gliadin, a protein in gluten.

Infection with Tropheryma whipplei, found in soil and sewage.
  • Possibly due to bacterial, fungal or coronavirus infection.

Clinical Features

Affects mainly proximal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea or steatorrhea.
  • Malabsorption: weight loss, vitamin deficiencies.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis (in some cases).

Affects mainly distal small intestine.

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain and bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Arthralgia (joint pain).
  • Fever.
  • Lymphadenopathy.
  • Neurological symptoms (cognitive impairment, seizures, ataxia in advanced stages, oculomasticatory myorhythmia).
  • Uveitis
  • Cardiac involvement (rare).

Affects entire small intestinal

 

Intestinal Features:

  • Chronic diarrhea.
  • Malabsorption, weight loss.
  • Abdominal pain, bloating.
 

Extraintestinal Features:

  • Anemia (often megaloblastic).

Histological Findings
 
  • Loss or flattening of intestinal villi (villous atrophy).
  • Hyperplastic crypts (crypt elongation).
  • Increased infiltration of lymphocytes, especially CD8+ T cells.
  • Increased plasma cells, lymphocytes, macrophages in lamina propria.
 
  • Villous blunting and atrophy.
  • Dense infiltration of lamina propria by macrophages containing PAS-positive granules.
  • Foamy macrophages laden with Tropheryma whipplei in various tissues (e.g., lymph nodes, CNS, synovial fluid).
 
  • Villous atrophy.
  • Crypt hyperplasia.
  • Increased inflammatory cells (similar to Celiac disease but without gliadin-specific immune response).

Investigations

Biopsy

Serologic Tests:

  • Most sensitive and most common antibody test: Anti-Tissue Transglutaminase Antibodies (Anti-tTG) - IgA and IgG
  • Most specific antibody test: Anti-Endomysial Antibodies (EMA) - IgA.
  • Anti-Deamidated Gliadin Peptide (DGP) Antibodies - IgA and IgG.
  • Anti-Gliadin Antibodies (AGA) - IgA and IgG.

Biopsy

PCR for Tropheryma whipplei DNA.

Immunohistochemistry for Tropheryma whipplei.

Biopsy

Response to Treatment: Antibiotic response helps confirm diagnosis.

Management
  • Lifelong gluten-free diet.
  • Nutritional supplementation: iron, folate, calcium, vitamin D.
  • Indications for steroids:
    • Refractory disease for 6-12 months
    • Celiac crisis
    • Lymphoma
  • Monitoring for complications

Prolonged antibiotic therapy:

  • Initially IV ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks.
  • Followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a year.
  • Tetracycline for 6 months.
  • Folate supplementation.
  • Some recommend a gluten-free diet.

Complications
  • Osteoporosis.
  • Malignancy (e.g., small bowel lymphoma).
  • Infertility.
  • Neurological complications (rare).
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Untreated disease can be fatal due to multi-organ involvement.
  • Relapses are common (especially CNS).
  • Nutritional deficiencies can lead to osteoporosis, cachexia.
  • Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin B12, folate).
  • Persistent malabsorption.
  • Possible relapse and chronic diarrhea.

questions.correct_answer: D. Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.
questions.explanation:
Type of Rejection

Hyperacute Rejection

Acute Rejection

Chronic Rejection

Acute Cellular Rejection

Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection

Description
  • Occurs immediately after transplant.
  • Mediated by preformed antibodies against graft endothelial cells.
  • Occurs within days to weeks after transplant.
  • Mediated by CD8+ T cells and CD4+ T cells.

Antibodies bind to graft endothelial cells, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • Develops over months to years.
  • Mediated by T cells.

Timing

Minutes to hours after transplant.

Days to weeks after transplant.

Days to months after transplant.

Months to years after transplant.

Type of Hypersensitivity Reaction

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Immunologic Mechanism
  • Pre-existing antibodies activate complement.
  • Causes endothelial injury and thrombosis.
  • CD8+ T cells destroy graft cells.
  • CD4+ T cells induce inflammation.
  • Antibodies against graft antigens activate complement.
  • Leads to graft inflammation.

T cell-mediated response causes graft fibrosis and dysfunction.

Treatment
  • No treatment.
  • Requires graft removal.

Immunosuppressive therapy (steroids, antithymocyte globulin).

Plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab, steroids.
  • No definitive treatment.
  • Supportive care and immunosuppression.

questions.text: A patient presented with uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

General Features

Spine and Joint involvement

Extra-articular manifestations
  • Inflammatory back pain: Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness.
  • Fatigue: A common and significant symptom.
  • Postural changes: Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck.
  • Enthesitis: Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia.
  • Peripheral joint involvement: Affects large joints like hips, knees, and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical.
  • Sacroiliac joint involvement: B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs.
  • Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms.

 
  • Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms.
  • Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis
  • Osteoporosis: This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion.

Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis

Tests

X-rays

MRI

  • HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%.
  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease.
  • Faecal Calprotectin: Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease.

Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints, such as:

  • Blurred cortical margins
  • Erosions and sclerosis
  • "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages)
  • Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages)
  • Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes
  • Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs.
  • Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes.
  • Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions.

HLA Type

Associated Conditions

HLA-A1
  • Reiter's syndrome
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

HLA-A2
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It is more similar to Crohn's disease than ulcerative colitis

options.label: D
options.text: Pathergy test positive is a criterion of ISG diagnostic criteria

questions.correct_answer: A. Ulcer over the dorsum of the penis
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • B/L uveitis (>50%) (Option C)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal
  • Presents similar to IBD (Crohn's disease > Ulcerative colitis) (Option B)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria (ITR-ICBD)

Two Points Each:

  • Genital aphthosis
  • Ocular lesions
 

One Point Each:

  • Oral aphthosis
  • Skin lesions
  • Vascular manifestations
  • Positive pathergy (Option D)

≥3 points needed for diagnosis

Laboratory Findings
  • Non-specific inflammation markers
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • ESR, CRP elevation
  • Leukocytosis

Helps rule out other conditions

Required Investigations
  • Ophthalmologic examination
  • Pathergy test
  • Skin biopsy if needed
  • Imaging, based on symptoms

Confirms involvement and monitors complications

Treatment

Mucocutaneous Treatment
  • Colchicine 1-2mg/day
  • Topical steroids
  • Topical sucralfate

Refractory: Systemic steroids, azathioprine

Ocular Treatment
  • Anterior: Topical steroids
  • Posterior: Steroids + azathioprine

Refractory: TNF inhibitors

Major Organ Involvement
  • Vascular: High-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide
  • Neurologic: High-dose steroids + immunosuppression

Requires aggressive therapy and monitoring

questions.text: All are hereditary causes of thrombosis except:
Most common cause of inherited coagulopathy is:
questions.explanation:
Primary disorders (Genetic)

Secondary disorders (Acquired)

Common

  • Factor V mutation
    • A single-nucleotide mutation (autosomal dominant inheritance) in the factor V gene makes factor V resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C.
  • Prothrombin mutation
    • A single nucleotide change (G20210A) in the 3′-untranslated region of the prothrombin gene is linked to hypercoagulability.
 

Rare

  • Antithrombin III deficiency (Option B)
  • Protein C deficiency (Option C)
  • Protein S deficiency (Option D)
 

Very rare

  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homozygous homocystinuria (deficiency of cystathionine β-synthetase)

Strong Risk Factors for Thrombosis

  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn)
  • Cancer
  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome
 

Other Risk Factors for Thrombosis

  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum)
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Smoking

questions.text: A young child presents with bleeding gums and bruising for the past two weeks. Bone marrow biopsy and flow cytometry have been performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL)

ALL is an acute-onset blood and bone marrow malignancy of B and T lymphoblasts characterised by the uncontrolled proliferation of abnormal and immature lymphocytes

Clinical features

  • Age: 2-8 years (Fast disease progression), adults: > 50 years.
  • Weight loss, Night sweats
  • Anemia: Easy fatigability and pallor
  • Bleeding: Epistaxis, easy bruising.
  • Leucocytopenia: Recurrent infections
  • Bone Marrow proliferation: Bone pain, sternal tenderness
  • Hepatosplenomegaly, Lymphadenopathy
  • CNS leukemia: Raised ICP, vomiting, and 6th nerve palsy
  • T cell tumors: Mediastinal and testicular mass.

Diagnosis

CBC is the first investigation performed while suspecting ALL:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb): Decreased, indicating normocytic normochromic anemia.
  • Hyperleukocytosis: TLC >100,000/µL can lead to leukostasis (more common in AML than ALL) with >20% Blasts.
  • Elderly Presentation: TLC often remains low throughout ALL.
  • Thrombocytopenia may be present.
 

Peripheral smear:

The smear shows a high percentage of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio. They often have a scant amount of cytoplasm and may exhibit nucleoli.

 

Bone Marrow aspiration shows blasts >20%.

  • It is also used to classify morphological types into L1, L2, and L3 in the FAB classification system.
 

FISH- Fluorescent in situ hybridization shows translocation of genes/chromosomes.

  • t(9:22) - ALL associated with the Philadelphia chromosome.
  • t(8:14) - Associated with Burkitt's leukemia
  • t(4:11)
  • t(1:19)
 

Flow cytometry:

  • CD10, also known as common acute lymphoblastic leukaemia antigen (CALLA), is a cell surface marker commonly used in the classification and diagnosis of leukaemias and lymphomas, particularly acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL).
  • B cell type - CD19+, CD79a+. (Option C)
  • T cell type - CD3+ (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases are correctly associated with their respective inclusion bodies?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Inclusion bodies

Rabies

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites usually devoid of inflammation.


 

Parkinson’s disease

Lewy bodies

  • These are single or multiple, cytoplasmic, eosinophilic, round to elongated inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo.
  • They are composed of fine filaments, densely packed in the core but loose at the rim; these filaments are composed of α-synuclein.

 

Multiple myeloma

The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

Malakoplakia

Michaelis Gutmann bodies: Laminated mineralized concretions resulting from calcium deposition in enlarged lysosomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option C)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.

As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.

High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases


 

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was diagnosed with croup. Which of the following is the most common causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent
  • Parainfluenza viruses (types 1,2 and 3) cause about 75% cases.
  • Other Viruses:
    • Influenza A and B,
    • Adenovirus,
    • Respiratory syncytial virus,
    • Measles.

Age Group
  • Most common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd year of life.

Initial Symptoms

These symptoms last 1-3 days before development of upper airway obstruction signs and symptoms.

  • Upper respiratory tract infection
  • Rhinorrhea
  • Pharyngitis
  • Mild cough
  • Low-grade fever

Progressive Symptoms

  • Barking cough
  • Hoarseness
  • Inspiratory stridor
  • Fever may reach 39- 40°C (102.2-104°F) or be absent
  • The child prefers to sit up in bed or be held upright
  • Symptoms worsen at night, recur over days and resolve within a week

Physical Examination Findings
  • Hoarse voice
  • Coryza
  • Inflamed pharynx
  • Slightly increased respiratory rate
  • Hypoxia and low oxygen saturation seen only in complete airway obstruction

Diagnosis

  • Clinical diagnosis
  • X-ray PA view of neck: Steeple sign, which is characteristic of subglottic narrowing

 

Treatment

  • Mainstay of Treatment: Focus on airway management and hypoxia treatment (O2).
  • Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine
  • Corticosteroids (dexamethasone):
    • Decrease edema in laryngeal mucosa
    • Oral steroids beneficial in mild croup
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.
